qas.question: What two compounds is zinc more reactive than?

answers.text: protective surface layer of oxide and carbonate

qas.question: What is used on many common items, such as chain link fences?
What is the only compound zinc is more reactive than?

plausible_answers.text: protective surface layer of oxide and carbonate

qas.question: How is zinc applied to wounds?
What is used on many rare items, such as chain link fences?

context:
Zinc is more reactive than <a0_0>iron or <b4_0>steel<b4_0/><a0_0/> and thus will attract almost all local oxidation until it completely corrodes away. A <a1_0><b5_0>protective surface layer of oxide and carbonate<b5_0/><a1_0/> (Zn
5(OH)
6(CO
3)
2) forms as the zinc corrodes. This protection lasts even after the zinc layer is scratched but degrades through time as the zinc corrodes away. The zinc is applied <a2_0><b6_0>electrochemically or as molten zinc<b6_0/><a2_0/> by hot-dip galvanizing or spraying. <a3_0><b7_0>Galvanization<b7_0/><a3_0/> is used on chain-link fencing, guard rails, suspension bridges, lightposts, metal roofs, heat exchangers, and car bodies.
